unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Drawing Conclusions: Employee Experience
question_text: Two large supermarket chains are interested in comparing the experience, in years, that their employees have. The summary statistics are below: Store $1$ : mean = $5.4, { S }_{ x }= 3.2, n = 34 $ Store $2$ : mean = $6.1, { S }_{ x }= 3.6, n = 36$ When performing a two-sample $T$ -test on $H_0: { u }_{ 1 }={ u }_{ 2 }$ versus $H_a:  { u }_{ 1 } < { u }_{ 2 } $ , what conclusion can be made? Define ${ u }_{ 1 }$ as the average experience at store $1$ , and ${ u }_{ 2 }$ as the average experience at store $2$ .

choices.text: Evidence exists that the storesâ€™ employees have the same amount of experience, at the 10 % 10 % level.
Evidence exists that the second has employees with more experience than those at the first store, significant at the 10 % 10 % level, but not at the 5 % 5 % or 1 % 1 % levels.
Evidence exists the second store has employees with more experience than those at the first store 1 1 , significant at the 5 % 5 % level.
There is insufficient evidence that employees at the second store have more experience than those at the first store, at the 10 % 10 % level.
There is no evidence of there not being a difference in employee experience between the two stores, at the 10 % 10 % level.
